{{Update|inaccurate=y|date=November 2010}} {{H5N1}} :''See [[Influenza pandemic]] for government preparation for an H5N1 pandemic'' The '''social impact of H5N1''' is the effect or influence of [[H5N1]] in human society; especially the financial, political, social, and personal responses to both actual and predicted deaths in birds, humans, and other animals. Billions of dollars are being raised and spent to research H5N1 and prepare for a potential [[avian influenza]] pandemic. Over ten billion dollars have been lost and over two hundred million birds have been killed to try to contain H5N1. People have reacted by buying less chicken causing poultry sales and prices to fall. Many individuals have stockpiled supplies for a possible flu pandemic.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}} ==Financial== On November 1, 2005 President George W. Bush unveiled the National Strategy To Safeguard Against The Danger of Pandemic Influenza[http://www.whitehouse.gov/homeland/pandemic-influenza.html Whitehouse.gov] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090109011356/http://www.whitehouse.gov/homeland/pandemic-influenza.html |date=2009-01-09 }} backed by a request to Congress for $7.1 billion to begin implementing the plan.[http://usinfo.state.gov/gi/Archive/2005/Nov/01-432345.html State.gov] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060914184240/http://usinfo.state.gov/gi/Archive/2005/Nov/01-432345.html |date=2006-09-14 }} On January 18, 2006 donor nations pledged two billion US dollars to combat bird flu at the two-day International Pledging Conference on Avian and Human Influenza held in China.[http://www.ens-newswire.com/ens/jan2006/2006-01-18-02.asp Newswire] Over ten billion dollars have been spent and over two hundred million birds have been killed to try to contain H5N1.[http://msnbc.msn.com/id/12033509/ MSNBC] [http://www.usaid.gov/about_usaid/acvfa/intro_ai.pdf US AID] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080815071811/http://www.usaid.gov/about_usaid/acvfa/intro_ai.pdf |date=2008-08-15 }} According to ''[[The New York Times]]'', due to the H5N1 threat, as of March 2006: "governments worldwide have spent billions planning for a potential influenza pandemic: buying medicines, running disaster drills, [and] developing strategies for tighter border controls."[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/16/business/16bird.html?_r=1&oref=slogin NYT] Investment strategies are being altered to manage the effects of H5N1.[http://www2.bmo.com/news/article/0,1257,contentCode-4922_divId-4_langId-1_navCode-112,00.html BMO Financial Group] This changes the valuations of trillions of dollars' worth of stocks worldwide as investors move assets in accordance with both fears and hopes. Poultry farming practices have changed due to H5N1: *killing millions of poultry *[[Vaccination|vaccinating]] poultry against bird flu *vaccinating poultry workers against [[human flu]] *limiting travel in areas where H5N1 is found *increasing farm hygiene *reducing contact between [[livestock]] and wild birds *reducing open-air [[wet market]]s *limiting workers contact with [[Cockfight|cock fighting]] *reducing purchases of live fowl *improving veterinary [[vaccine]] availability and cost.[http://www.cfr.org/pub8198/laurie_garrett_anthony_s_fauci_michael_osterholm_rita_colwell/the_threat_of_global_pandemics.php Council on Foreign Relations] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081013053617/http://www.cfr.org/pub8198/laurie_garrett_anthony_s_fauci_michael_osterholm_rita_colwell/the_threat_of_global_pandemics.php |date=2008-10-13 }} For example, after nearly two years of using mainly culling to control the virus, the [[Vietnam]] government in 2005 adopted a combination of mass poultry vaccination, disinfecting, culling, information campaigns and bans on live poultry in cities.[http://today.reuters.co.uk/news/newsArticle.aspx?type=worldNews&storyID=2006-04-28T080147Z_01_HAN5054_RTRUKOC_0_UK-BIRDFLU-VIETNAM.xml Reuters]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} article ''Vietnam to unveil advanced plan to fight bird flu'' published on April 28, 2006 The cost of poultry farming has increased, while the cost to consumers has gone down due to fears from H5N1 driving demand below supply, resulting in devastating losses for many poultry farmers. Poor poultry farmers can't afford mandated measures keeping their bird livestock from contact with wild birds (and other measures) thus risking losing their livelihood altogether. Multinational poultry farming is increasingly becoming a profit loser as H5N1 achieves status as endemic in wild birds worldwide.[http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/IRIN/a13fd43bc74b6209dc90f6d849ffa45b.htm Poultry sector suffers despite absence of bird flu] Financial ruin for poor poultry farmers, that can be as severe as threatening starvation, has caused some to commit suicide and many others to stop cooperating with efforts to deal with H5N1; further increasing the human toll, the spread of the disease and the chances for a pandemic mutation.[http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/BKK260524.htm Reuters] article ''Cambodian ostracised for reporting bird flu'' published on April 12, 2006. [http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/BOM269913.htm Reuters] article ''Nine poultry farmers commit suicide in flu-hit India'' published on April 12, 2006. [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/04/14/world/africa/14egypt.html?_r=1&oref=slogin New York Times] article ''In the Nile Delta, Bird Flu Preys on Ignorance and Poverty'' published on April 13, 2006. ==Political== [[United States Department of Health and Human Services|US HHS]] Secretary [[Michael O. Leavitt]] has said "Everything you say in advance of a [[pandemic]] is [[alarmist]]; anything you do after it starts is inadequate."{{Cite web |url=http://www.richmond.com/health/output.aspx?Article_ID=4179051&Vertical_ID=127&tier=1&position=5 |title=Virginia Pandemic Influenza Summit informs community partners about pandemic influenza plans at the national and state level |access-date=2006-03-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926213521/http://www.richmond.com/health/output.aspx?Article_ID=4179051&Vertical_ID=127&tier=1&position=5 |archive-date=2007-09-26 |dead-url=yes |df= }} H5N1, like everything else, is subject to [[spin (public relations)|political spin]]; wherein every interest group picks and chooses among the facts to support their favorite cause resulting in a distortion of the overall picture, the motivations of the people involved and the believability of the predictions. [[Donald Rumsfeld]], formerly [[United States Secretary of Defense]], is a past board member and current minor shareholder of [[Gilead Sciences]] which owns [[intellectual property rights]] to [[Oseltamivir]] (also called "Tamiflu"). In November 2005, George W. Bush urged Congress to pass 7.1 billion in emergency funding to prepare for the possible bird flu pandemic, of which one billion is solely dedicated to the purchase, and distribution of Tamiflu. Some believe ''The deadly H5N1 strain of bird flu is essentially a problem of industrial poultry practices.''[http://www.grain.org/briefings/?id=194 Grain international, non-profit foundation] [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/4721598.stm BBC news] [http://cnn.netscape.cnn.com/news/story.jsp?id=2006032808270002118201&dt=20060328082700&w=RTR&coview= CNN] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060616201320/http://cnn.netscape.cnn.com/news/story.jsp?id=2006032808270002118201&dt=20060328082700&w=RTR&coview= |date=2006-06-16 }} Others have a more nuanced position. According to the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] article ''H5N1 Outbreaks and Enzootic Influenza'' by [[Robert G. Webster]] et al.:"Transmission of highly pathogenic H5N1 from domestic poultry back to migratory waterfowl in western China has increased the geographic spread. The spread of H5N1 and its likely reintroduction to domestic poultry increase the need for good agricultural vaccines. In fact, the root cause of the continuing H5N1 pandemic threat may be the way the pathogenicity of H5N1 viruses is masked by cocirculating influenza viruses or bad agricultural vaccines."[https://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/EID/vol12no01/05-1024.htm CDC] ''H5N1 Outbreaks and Enzootic Influenza'' by [[Robert G. Webster]] et al. Dr. Robert Webster explains: "If you use a good vaccine you can prevent the transmission within poultry and to humans. But if they have been using vaccines now [in China] for several years, why is there so much bird flu? There is bad vaccine that stops the disease in the bird but the bird goes on pooping out virus and maintaining it and changing it. And I think this is what is going on in China. It has to be. Either there is not enough vaccine being used or there is substandard vaccine being used. Probably both. It's not just China. We can't blame China for substandard vaccines. I think there are substandard vaccines for influenza in poultry all over the world."[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/10639567/ MSNBC quoting Reuters quoting Robert G. Webster] In response to the same concerns, Reuters reports Hong Kong infectious disease expert Lo Wing-lok saying that "The issue of vaccines has to take top priority", and Julie Hall, in charge of the WHO's outbreak response in China, saying that China's vaccinations could be "masking" the virus.{{cite web |url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/HKG28205.htm |title=China H5N1 outbreak puts vaccines under spotlight |date=17 March 2006 |access-date= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060318225839/http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/HKG28205.htm |archive-date=18 March 2006}} The BBC reported that Dr Wendy Barclay, a virologist at the University of Reading, UK said: "The Chinese have made a vaccine based on reverse genetics made with H5N1 antigens, and they have been using it. There has been a lot of criticism of what they have done, because they have protected their chickens against death from this virus but the chickens still get infected; and then you get drift - the virus mutates in response to the antibodies - and now we have a situation where we have five or six 'flavours' of H5N1 out there."[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/4737276.stm BBC] ''Bird flu vaccine no silver bullet'' February 22, 2006 Some have called for tax breaks due to H5N1. A May 7, 2006 report from India E-News states that: "Pakistani poultry farmers have sought a 10-year tax exemption to support their dwindling business after the detection of the H5N1 strain of bird flu triggered a fall in demand and prices, a poultry trader said. "We have asked the government to give us tax exemption on income from the poultry business for at least 10 years to meet losses caused by the bird flu scare", Abdul Basit told DPA. Basit, vice president of the Chamber of Commerce and Industry (LCCI) in the country's commercial hub of Lahore, was part of a delegation of the Pakistan Poultry Association, which met food ministry officials to present their demand. The federal poultry board of the food ministry is to meet on May 9 to consider the tax-cut demand for the poultry business in the upcoming national budget due in mid-June."[http://indiaenews.com/2006-05/6960-pakistani-poultry-demands-10-year-tax-holiday.htm India eNews] article ''Pakistani poultry industry demands 10-year tax holiday'' published May 7, 2006 ==Social== [[Reuters]] reported that [[WHO]] expert Hassan al-Bushra said:
Even now, we remain unsure about [[Tamiflu]]'s real effectiveness. As for a vaccine, work cannot start on it until the emergence of a new virus, and we predict it would take six to nine months to develop it. For the moment, we cannot by any means count on a potential vaccine to prevent the spread of a contagious influenza virus, whose various precedents in the past 90 years have been highly pathogenic. However, it is crucial that countries in the Middle East invest and start developing their own research and technical facilities, where they can produce their own drugs when the time comes rather than wait to import expensive medicines from abroad at the risk of their population.[http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/IRIN/e83d17668fc60eb55518a76c1de858fd.htm Reuters article ''MIDDLE EAST: Interview with WHO experts Hassan al-Bushra and John Jabbour''] 2 April 2006
If a pandemic occurs, local response will be more important than national or international response, as every community will have its own resources swamped dealing with its own problems.{{Cite web |url=http://www.richmond.com/health/output.aspx?Article_ID=4179051&Vertical_ID=127&tier=1&position=5 |title="Any community that fails to prepare with the expectation the federal government will come to the rescue will be tragically wrong." - US HHS |access-date=2006-03-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926213521/http://www.richmond.com/health/output.aspx?Article_ID=4179051&Vertical_ID=127&tier=1&position=5 |archive-date=2007-09-26 |dead-url=yes |df= }} International groups, nations, local governments, corporations, schools, and groups of all kinds have made plans and run drills to prepare for an H5N1 pandemic. Online avian flu forums have received increasing attention.[http://www.avianflutalk.com/ Avian flu forum] Self-help groups have organized to provide news and information about resources, aid and relief efforts in preparation for avian flu.[http://avianfluhelp.blogspot.com/ Avian flu help] British reports warn that in response to an [[influenza pandemic]] local groups will not be able to rely on the armed forces, widespread infection could occur in days not months, an effective vaccine can not be counted on, and the huge death toll could swamp mortuaries so "A key point for local planning is likely to be the identification of potential sites for the location of facilities for the temporary storage of bodies".[http://news.scotsman.com/health.cfm?id=508792006 Scotsman News] Report on leaked British study. ==Personal== Many individuals have stockpiled supplies (Tamiflu, food, water, etc.) for a possible flu pandemic.[http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&q=Many+individuals+have+stockpiled+supplies+%28Tamiflu%2C+food%2C+water%2C+etc%29+for+a+possible+flu+pandemic.&btnG=Google+Search] Individuals have started web sites and companies using interest and ignorance in H5N1 to sell information, cures, and advertising space. Some even use concern over H5N1 to find victims for their [[malware]].[https://www.theregister.co.uk/2006/03/27/spyware_diy/ The Register] article "S'kiddies get into spyware for just $15" by John Leyden published March 27, 2006 accessed February 28, 2007 says "Spam samples trapped by internet security firm Sophos use newsworthy topics to lure unwary users. One presents itself as a warning about the deadly H5N1 bird flu virus, providing links to the bogus website, purporting to offer health advice. [...] Surfers visiting these websites will find themselves exposed to JavaScript code that attempts to take advantage of known web browser and Windows vulnerabilities to download malware." A significant effect of H5N1 has been personal fear concerning the unknown, even by those most in-the-know. Dr. [[David Nabarro]], chief avian flu coordinator for the United Nations, describes himself as "quite scared"; says avian flu has too many unanswered questions; and if the disease starts spreading to humans, borders will close, airports will shut down, and travelers everywhere will be stranded.[http://www.iht.com/articles/2006/03/27/news/worrier.php NYT article picked up by IHT] With evaluations of the threat ranging from those who say it is a hoax to those who warn of billions of humans dying, uncertainty and fear motivate personal behaviors around the world affecting many people even before the threat becomes reality. ==Pop culture== The 1998 chart-topping hit song "[[One Week (song)|One Week]]" by [[Barenaked Ladies]] includes the lines "Chickity China the Chinese chicken / Have a drumstick and your brain stops tickin'", a reference to the outbreaks of H5N1 in Hong Kong around the time the song was written. ==Compared to annual flu season== {{main|Flu season}} The annual flu season deaths and costs caused by viruses other than H5N1 provide a point of contrast - something to compare against. According to the United States Government, the annual flu in the United States:
results in approximately 36,000 deaths and more than 200,000 hospitalizations each year. In addition to this human toll, influenza is annually responsible for a total cost of over $10 billion in the United States. A pandemic, or worldwide outbreak of a new influenza virus, could dwarf this impact by overwhelming our health and medical capabilities, potentially resulting in hundreds of thousands of deaths, millions of hospitalizations, and hundreds of billions of dollars in direct and indirect costs.[http://www.whitehouse.gov/homeland/pandemic-influenza.html Message from President Bush] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090109011356/http://www.whitehouse.gov/homeland/pandemic-influenza.html |date=2009-01-09 }}
The ''[[New England Journal of Medicine]]'' reported that: "A study by the Congressional Budget Office estimates that the consequences of a severe pandemic could, in the United States, include 200 million people infected, 90 million clinically ill, and 2 million dead. The study estimates that 30 percent of all workers would become ill and 2.5 percent would die, with 30 percent of workers missing a mean of three weeks of work — resulting in a decrease in the gross domestic product of 5 percent. Furthermore, 18 million to 45 million people would require outpatient care, and economic costs would total approximately $675 billion."[http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/full/354/13/1411 New England Journal of Medicine] Volume 354:1411-1413 - March 30, 2006 - Number 13 - ''Vaccines against Avian Influenza — A Race against Time'' One study concludes that a pandemic that reduced the available dock workers by 28% would cut the throughput capacity for containers arriving at American ports on the West coast by 45%.Pandemic influenza, worker absenteeism and impacts on freight transportation | From Proc 41st Hawaii Intl Conf Syst Sci, published online Apr 9 {{cite web |url=http://www.wpro.who.int/NR/rdonlyres/FD4AC2FD-B7C8-4A13-A32C-6CF328A0C036/0/Slide4.jpg |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-04-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081119194526/http://www.wpro.who.int/NR/rdonlyres/FD4AC2FD-B7C8-4A13-A32C-6CF328A0C036/0/Slide4.jpg |archivedate=2008-11-19 |df= }} ==See also== *[[Bird flu in India]] *[[Fatal Contact: Bird Flu in America]] (2006 film) *[[Fujian flu]] *[[Influenza Genome Sequencing Project]] *[[International Partnership on Avian and Pandemic Influenza]] *[[Disease surveillance]] *[[Pandemic Severity Index]] ==References== {{Reflist|3}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Social Effects Of H5n1}} [[Category:Influenza A virus subtype H5N1]] [[Category:Global health]] [[Category:Poultry farming]]

{{redirect|Space junk|other uses|Space Junk (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} [[File:Debris-GEO1280.jpg|thumb|300px|alt=Earth from space, surrounded by small white dots|A computer-generated image representing space debris as could be seen from [[high Earth orbit]]. The two main debris fields are the ring of objects in [[geosynchronous orbit|geosynchronous Earth orbit]] (GEO) and the cloud of objects in [[low Earth orbit]] (LEO).]]
Initially, the term '''space debris''' referred to the natural debris found in the solar system: [[asteroid]]s, [[comet]]s, and [[meteoroid]]s. However, with the 1979 beginning of the NASA Orbital Debris Program,<ref>[https://orbitaldebris.jsc.nasa.gov/ NASA Orbital Debris Program]</ref> the term also refers to the debris (alt. '''space waste''' or '''space garbage''') from the mass of defunct, artificially created objects in space, especially [[Geocentric orbit|Earth orbit]]. These include old [[satellite]]s and spent [[rocket stage]]s, as well as the fragments from their disintegration and [[collision]]s.
As of December 2016, five [[satellite collision]]s have generated space debris.{{cn|date=August 2018}} Space debris is also known as ''orbital debris'', ''space junk'', ''space waste'', ''space trash'', ''space litter'' or ''space garbage''.<ref> [http://www.spaceacademy.net.au/watch/debris/debris.htm GUIDE TO SPACE DEBRIS from the spaceacademy.net.au]</ref>
{{as of|2016|7|5}}, the [[United States Strategic Command]] tracked a total of 17,852 artificial objects in orbit above the Earth,<ref name=ODQN-201607>{{cite newsletter |url=https://orbitaldebris.jsc.nasa.gov/quarterly-news/pdfs/odqnv20i3.pdf |title=Orbital Debris Quarterly News |volume=20 |issue=3 |page=8 |publisher=[[NASA]] |date=July 2016 |access-date=10 October 2016}}</ref> including 1,419 operational satellites.<ref name=ucs>{{cite web |title=UCS Satellite Database |date=11 August 2016 |work=Nuclear Weapons & Global Security |publisher=[[Union of Concerned Scientists]] |url=http://www.ucsusa.org/nuclear_weapons_and_global_security/space_weapons/technical_issues/ucs-satellite-database.html |accessdate=10 October 2016}}</ref> However, these are just objects large enough to be tracked. {{as of|July 2013}}, more than 170 million bits of debris smaller than {{convert|1|cm|abbr=on|sigfig=1}}, about 670,000 pieces of debris 1–10 cm, and around 29,000 larger pieces were estimated to be in orbit around the earth.<ref name="esadebris2013">[http://www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Space_Engineering_Technology/Clean_Space/How_many_space_debris_objects_are_currently_in_orbit "How many space debris objects are currently in orbit?"] ''ESA'', July 2013. Retrieved 6 February 2016</ref> Collisions with debris have become a hazard to spacecraft; they cause damage akin to [[sandblasting]], especially to solar panels and optics like telescopes or [[star tracker]]s that cannot be covered with a [[hypervelocity ballistic shield|ballistic]] [[Whipple shield]] (unless it is transparent).<ref name=nasa20090428> {{cite web |url= http://images.spaceref.com/news/2009/ODMediaBriefing28Apr09-1.pdf |title= The Threat of Orbital Debris and Protecting NASA Space Assets from Satellite Collisions |date= 2009 |publisher=Space Reference }}</ref>
Below {{convert|2000|km|abbr=on}} Earth-[[orbital altitude|altitude]], pieces of debris are denser than [[meteoroid]]s; most are dust from solid rocket motors, surface erosion debris like paint flakes, and frozen coolant from [[RORSAT]] (nuclear-powered satellites). For comparison, the [[International Space Station]] orbits in the {{convert|300|–|400|km}} range, and the [[2009 satellite collision]] and [[2007 Chinese anti-satellite missile test|2007 antisat test]] occurred at {{convert|800|to|900|km}} altitude.<ref name=nasa9> {{citation |url= http://images.spaceref.com/news/2009/ODMediaBriefing28Apr09-1.pdf |title= The Threat of Orbital Debris and Protecting NASA Space Assets from Satellite Collisions |date= 2009 |publisher= Space Reference }}</ref> The ISS has [[Whipple shielding]]; however, known debris with a collision chance over 1/10,000 are avoided by [[orbital maneuver|maneuvering]] the station.
The [[Kessler syndrome]], a runaway [[chain reaction]] of collisions exponentially increasing the amount of debris, has been hypothesized to ensue beyond a critical density. This could affect useful polar-orbiting bands, increases the cost of protection for spacecraft missions and could destroy live satellites. Whether Kessler syndrome is already underway has been debated.<ref name=k09 /><ref>Lisa Grossman, [https://www.wired.com/wiredscience/tag/kessler-syndrome/ "NASA Considers Shooting Space Junk with Lasers"], ''wired'', 15 March 2011.</ref> The measurement, mitigation, and potential removal of debris are conducted by some participants in the [[space industry]].
== Characterization ==
=== {{anchor|Large vs. small}}Size === There are estimated to be over 51 million pieces of debris smaller than {{convert|1|cm|abbr=on}} as of July 2013. There are approximately 670,000 pieces from one to ten cm. The current count of large debris (defined as 10 cm across or larger<ref name="technasa">[http://www.orbitaldebris.jsc.nasa.gov/library/UN_Report_on_Space_Debris99.pdf "Technical report on space debris"], p. 15, United Nations, New York, 1999.</ref>) is 29,000.<ref name="esadebris2013"/> The technical measurement cutoff is c. {{convert|3|mm|abbr=on}}.<ref name="nasadebris2012">[http://orbitaldebris.jsc.nasa.gov/faqs.html#3 "Orbital Debris FAQ: How much orbital debris is currently in Earth orbit?"] ''NASA'', March 2012. Retrieved 31 January 2016</ref> Over 98 percent of the 1,900 tons of debris in low Earth orbit (as of 2002) was accounted for by about 1,500 objects, each over {{convert|100|kg|abbr=on}}.<ref>Joseph Carroll, [http://www.niac.usra.edu/files/studies/final_report/800Carroll.pdf "Space Transport Development Using Orbital Debris"], NASA Institute for Advanced Concepts, 2 December 2002, p. 3.</ref> Total mass is mostly constant despite addition of many smaller objects, since they reenter the atmosphere sooner. Using a 2008 figure of 8,500 known items, it is estimated at {{convert|5500|t|lb|abbr=on}}.<ref>Robin McKie and Michael Day, [https://www.theguardian.com/science/2008/feb/24/spaceexplorationspacejunk "Warning of catastrophe from mass of 'space junk'"] ''The Observer'', 24 February 2008.</ref>
=== {{anchor|Debris in LEO}}Low Earth orbit (LEO) === [[File:Space Junk.jpg|thumb|alt=Earth from space, with space debris enhanced|Space debris in LEO, with sizes exaggerated]]
In LEO there are few "universal orbits" which keep spacecraft in particular rings (in contrast to GEO, a single widely used orbit). The closest are [[sun-synchronous orbit]]s that keep a constant angle between the Sun and the [[Orbital plane (astronomy)|orbital plane]]; they are [[Polar orbit|polar]], meaning they cross over the polar regions. LEO satellites orbit in many planes, up to 15 times a day, causing frequent approaches between objects (the density of objects is much higher in LEO).<ref>Matt Ford, [https://arstechnica.com/science/news/2009/02/orbiting-space-junk-heightens-risk-of-satellite-catastrophes.ars "Orbiting space junk heightens risk of satellite catastrophes."] ''Ars Technica'', 27 February 2009.</ref>
Orbits are further changed by [[Perturbation (astronomy)|perturbations]] (which in LEO include unevenness of the Earth's gravitational field), and collisions can occur from any direction. For these reasons, the Kessler syndrome applies mostly to the LEO region; impacts occur at up to 16 km/s (twice the [[orbital speed]]) if head-on – the [[2009 satellite collision]] occurred at 11.7 km/s,<ref>[http://www.esa.int/esaMI/Space_Debris/1112600510257_0.html "What are hypervelocity impacts?"] ''ESA'', 19 February 2009.</ref> creating much [[spall]] in the critical size range. These can cross other orbits and lead to a cascade effect. A large-enough collision (e.g. between a space station and a defunct satellite) could make [[low Earth orbit]] impassable.<ref name="k09">{{cite web | url = http://webpages.charter.net/dkessler/files/KesSym.html | title = The Kessler Syndrome | date = 8 March 2009 | author = Donald J. Kessler | access-date = 22 September 2009 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100527195029/http://webpages.charter.net/dkessler/files/KesSym.html | archive-date = 27 May 2010 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
Manned missions are mostly at {{convert|400|km|abbr=on}} and below, where air drag helps clear zones of fragments. Atmospheric expansion as a result of [[space weather]] raises the critical altitude by increasing drag; in the 90s, it was a factor in reduced debris density.<ref name=k9165 /> Another was fewer launches by Russia; the USSR made most of their launches in the 1970s and 1980s.<ref name=k7>Klinkrad, p. 7.</ref>
=== {{anchor|Debris at higher altitudes}}Higher altitudes === At higher altitudes, where air drag is less significant, orbital decay takes longer. Slight [[Drag (physics)|atmospheric drag]], [[Lunar theory|lunar perturbations]], Earth's gravity perturbations, [[solar wind]] and solar [[radiation pressure]] can gradually bring debris down to lower altitudes (where it decays), but at very high altitudes this may take millennia.<ref name=kam68>Kessler 1991, p. 268.</ref> Although high-altitude orbits are less commonly used than LEO and the onset of the problem is slower, the numbers progress toward the critical threshold more quickly.{{contradict-inline|date=December 2015}}{{page needed|date=December 2015}}<ref>{{Cite journal| bibcode=2005ESASP.587..113S | title=Optical observation of space debris in high-altitude orbits | journal=Proceedings of the 4th European Conference on Space Debris (ESA SP-587). 18–20 April 2005 | volume=587 | page=113 | author1=Schildknecht | first1=T. | last2=Musci | first2=R. | last3=Flury | first3=W. | last4=Kuusela | first4=J. | last5=De Leon | first5=J. | last6=Dominguez Palmero | first6=L. De Fatima | year=2005 }}</ref>
Many communications satellites are in [[geostationary orbit]]s (GEO), clustering over specific targets and sharing the same orbital path. Although velocities are low between GEO objects, when a satellite becomes derelict (such as [[Telstar 401]]) it assumes a [[geosynchronous orbit]]; its [[orbital inclination]] increases about .8° and its speed increases about {{convert|100|mph}} per year. Impact velocity peaks at about {{convert|1.5|km/s|abbr=on}}. [[Perturbation (astronomy)|Orbital perturbations]] cause longitude drift of the inoperable spacecraft and [[precession]] of the orbital plane. Close approaches (within 50 meters) are estimated at one per year.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110718231404/http://www.weblab.dlr.de/rbrt/pdf/ISSFD_89085.pdf "Colocation Strategy and Collision Avoidance for the Geostationary Satellites at 19 Degrees West."] ''CNES Symposium on Space Dynamics'', 6–10 November 1989.</ref> The collision debris pose less short-term risk than from an LEO collision, but the satellite would likely become inoperable. Large objects, such as [[Space-based solar power|solar-power satellites]], are especially vulnerable to collisions.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = van der Ha | first1 = J. C. | last2 = Hechler | first2 = M. | year = 1981| title = The Collision Probability of Geostationary Satellites | url = http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1981rome.iafcR....V | journal = 32nd International Astronautical Congress | volume = 1981 | issue = | page = 23 | bibcode=1981rome.iafcR....V}}</ref>
Although the [[International Telecommunication Union|ITU]] now requires proof a satellite can be moved out of its orbital slot at the end of its lifespan, studies suggest this is insufficient.<ref name= Anselmo>{{cite journal | last1 = Anselmo | first1 = L. | last2 = Pardini | first2 = C. | year = 2000 | title = Collision Risk Mitigation in Geostationary Orbit | url = | journal = Space Debris | volume = 2 | issue = 2| pages = 67–82 | doi = 10.1023/A:1021255523174 }}</ref> Since GEO orbit is too distant to accurately measure objects under {{convert|1|m|abbr=on}}, the nature of the problem is not well known.<ref>''Orbital Debris'', p. 86.</ref> Satellites could be moved to empty spots in GEO, requiring less maneuvring and making it easier to predict future motion.<ref>''Orbital Debris'', p. 152.</ref> Satellites or boosters in other orbits, especially stranded in [[geostationary transfer orbit]], are an additional concern due to their typically high crossing velocity.
Despite efforts to reduce risk, spacecraft collisions have occurred. The [[European Space Agency]] telecom satellite [[Olympus-1]] was struck by a meteoroid on 11 August 1993 and eventually moved to a [[graveyard orbit]].<ref name="The Olympus failure">[http://www.selkirkshire.demon.co.uk/analoguesat/olympuspr.html "The Olympus failure"] ''ESA press release'', 26 August 1993. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070911181644/http://www.selkirkshire.demon.co.uk/analoguesat/olympuspr.html |date=11 September 2007 }}</ref> On 29 March 2006, the Russian [[Express (satellite)|Express-AM11]] communications satellite was struck by an unknown object and rendered inoperable;<ref name=srdc20060419>[http://www.spaceref.com/news/viewsr.html?pid=20320 "Notification for Express-AM11 satellite users in connection with the spacecraft failure"] ''Russian Satellite Communications Company'', 19 April 2006.</ref> its engineers had enough contact time with the satellite to send it into a graveyard orbit.
== {{anchor|Sources of debris}}Sources ==
=== Dead spacecraft === {{See also|Kosmos 954|Kosmos 1402|Category:Derelict satellites orbiting Earth|label 3=Derelict satellites orbiting Earth|}} [[File:Vanguard 1.jpg|thumb|alt=Small, round satellite with six rod antennas radiating from it|Vanguard 1 is expected to remain in orbit for 240 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2008-03/nrl-vic031308.php |title=Vanguard I celebrates 50 years in space |publisher=Eurekalert.org |date= |accessdate=2013-10-04}}</ref>]] In 1958, the United States launched [[Vanguard I]] into a [[medium Earth orbit]] (MEO). {{As of|2009|10}}, it, and the upper stage of its launch rocket, are the oldest surviving man-made space objects still in orbit.<ref name="usaweekend">Julian Smith, [http://www.usaweekend.com/07_issues/070826/070826space.html#junk "Space Junk"]{{dead link|date=July 2011}} ''USA Weekend'', 26 August 2007.</ref><ref>[http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2008-03/nrl-vic031308.php Vanguard 50 years]</ref> In a catalog of known launches until July 2009, the [[Union of Concerned Scientists]] listed 902 operational satellites<ref>[http://www.ucsusa.org/nuclear_weapons_and_global_security/space_weapons/technical_issues/ucs-satellite-database.html "UCS Satellite Database"] ''Union of Concerned Scientists'', 16 July 2009.</ref> from a known population of 19,000 large objects and about 30,000 objects launched.
An example of additional dead satellite debris are the remains of the 1970s/80s [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] [[RORSAT]] naval surveillance satellite program. The satellite's BES-5 [[Nuclear reactor technology|nuclear reactor]] were cooled with a coolant loop of [[NaK|sodium-potassium alloy]], creating a potential problem when the satellite reached end of life. While many satellites were nominally boosted into medium-altitude [[graveyard orbit]]s, not all were. Even satellites which had been properly moved to a higher orbit had an eight-percent probability of puncture and coolant release over a 50-year period. The coolant freezes into droplets of solid sodium-potassium alloy,<ref name=wiedemann2009>C. Wiedemann et al, "Size distribution of NaK droplets for MASTER-2009", ''Proceedings of the 5th European Conference on Space Debris'', 30 March-2 April 2009, (ESA SP-672, July 2009).</ref> forming additional debris.<ref name=rossi1997>A. Rossi et al, [http://apollo.isti.cnr.it/rossi/publications/iaf97/node7.html "Effects of the RORSAT NaK Drops on the Long Term Evolution of the Space Debris Population"] {{dead link|date=July 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}, University of Pisa, 1997.</ref><ref name=rossi1997/>
These events continue to occur. For example, in February 2015, the [[USAF]] [[Defense Meteorological Satellite Program]] Flight 13 (DMSP-F13) exploded on orbit, creating at least 149 debris objects, which were expected to remain in orbit for decades.<ref name=sn20150506>{{cite news |last1=Gruss|first1=Mike |title=DMSP-F13 Debris To Stay On Orbit for Decades |url=http://spacenews.com/dmsp-f13-debris-to-stay-on-orbit-for-decades/ |accessdate=7 May 2015 |work=Space News |date=2015-05-06 }}</ref>
=== Lost equipment === [[File:Black_Knight_Satellite_(cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|A drifting [[Space blanket|thermal blanket]] photographed in 1998 during [[STS-88]].]] According to [[Edward Tufte]]'s book ''Envisioning Information'', space debris includes a glove lost by astronaut [[Ed White (astronaut)|Ed White]] on the first American [[Extra-vehicular activity|space-walk]] (EVA); a camera lost by [[Michael Collins (astronaut)|Michael Collins]] near [[Gemini 10]]; a [[Space blanket|thermal blanket]] lost during [[STS-88]]; garbage bags jettisoned by Soviet [[cosmonauts]] during [[Mir]]'s 15-year life,<ref name="usaweekend" /> a wrench and a toothbrush. [[Sunita Williams]] of [[STS-116]] lost a camera during an EVA. During an [[STS-120]] EVA to reinforce a torn solar panel, a pair of pliers was lost, and in an [[STS-126]] EVA, [[Heidemarie Stefanyshyn-Piper]] lost a briefcase-sized tool bag.<ref>See image [[:File:Bye tool bag.jpg|here]].</ref>
=== Boosters === [[File:Delta-II Stage2 XSS-10.jpg|thumb|Spent upper stage of a [[Delta II]] rocket, photographed by the [[XSS 10]] satellite]] In characterizing the problem of space debris, it was learned that much debris was due to rocket upper stages (e.g. the [[Inertial Upper Stage]]) which end up in orbit, and break up due to decomposition of [[Passivation (spacecraft)|unvented]] unburned fuel.<ref name=loftus1989>{{cite book |last=Loftus|first=Joseph P. |title=Orbital Debris from Upper-stage Breakup |year=1989 |publisher=AIAA |page=227 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=RehH7b_kmNEC |isbn=978-1-60086-376-9 }}</ref> However, a major known impact event involved an (intact) [[Ariane (rocket family)|Ariane]] booster.<ref name="Klinkrad, p. 2" /> Although NASA and the [[United States Air Force]] now require upper-stage passivation, other launchers{{vague|date=January 2016}} do not. Lower stages, like the Space Shuttle's [[solid rocket booster]]s or [[Apollo program]]'s [[Saturn IB]] [[launch vehicle]]s, do not reach orbit.<ref>Some return to Earth intact, see [http://www.reentrynews.com/recovered.html this list] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091028021045/http://www.reentrynews.com/recovered.html |date=28 October 2009 }} for examples.</ref>
On 11 March 2000 a Chinese [[Long March (rocket family)|Long March 4]] [[CBERS-1]] upper stage exploded in orbit, creating a debris cloud.<ref>Phillip Anz-Meador and Mark Matney, "[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2004AdSpR..34..987A An assessment of the NASA explosion fragmentation model to 1 mm characteristic sizes]" ''Advances in Space Research'', Volume 34 Issue 5 (2004), pp. 987–992.</ref><ref name=srdc20000810>[http://www.spaceref.com/news/viewpr.html?pid=2464 "Debris from explosion of Chinese rocket detected by University of Chicago satellite instrument"], University of Chicago press release, 10 August 2000.</ref> A Russian [[Briz-M]] booster stage exploded in orbit over South Australia on 19 February 2007. Launched on 28 February 2006 carrying an [[Arabsat-4A]] [[communications satellite]], it malfunctioned before it could use up its propellant. Although the explosion was captured on film by astronomers, due to the orbit path the debris cloud has been difficult to measure with radar. By 21 February 2007, over 1,000 fragments were identified.<ref>[http://www.spaceweather.com/archive.php?view=1&day=21&month=02&year=2007 "Rocket Explosion"], Spaceweather.com, 22 February 2007. Retrieved 21 February 2007.</ref><ref>Ker Than, [http://www.space.com/news/070221_rocket_explodes.html "Rocket Explodes Over Australia, Showers Space with Debris"] ''Space.com'', 21 February 2007. Retrieved 21 February 2007.</ref> A 14 February 2007 breakup was recorded by Celestrak.<ref>[http://celestrak.com/events/debris-events.asp "Recent Debris Events"] ''celestrak.com'', 16 March 2007. Retrieved 14 July 2001.</ref> Eight breakups occurred in 2006, the most since 1993.<ref>Jeff Hecht, [https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn10979-spate-of-rocket-breakups-creates-new-space-junk.html "Spate of rocket breakups creates new space junk"], ''NewScientist'', 17 January 2007. Retrieved 16 March 2007.</ref> Another Briz-M broke up on 16 October 2012 after a failed 6 August [[Proton-M]] launch. The amount and size of the debris was unknown.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.zarya.info/Gallimaufry/120707ProtonFailure.php |title=Proton Launch Failure 2012 Aug 6 |date=21 October 2012 |accessdate=21 October 2012 |publisher=Zarya |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121010150558/http://www.zarya.info/Gallimaufry/120707ProtonFailure.php |archivedate=10 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> A [[Long March 7]] rocket booster created a fireball visible from portions of Utah, Nevada, Colorado, Idaho and California on the evening of 27 July 2016; its disintegration was widely reported on social media.<ref name="Long March 7 booster re-rentry visibile of much of Western U.W.">{{cite web | url=http://www.space.com/33581-amazing-fireball-from-chinese-rocket-space-junk-video.html | title=Amazing Fireball Over Western US Caused by Chinese Space Junk | publisher=space.com | date=2016-07-28 | accessdate=2016-07-28 | author=Mike, Wall}}</ref>
=== {{anchor|Debris from and as a weapon}}Weapons === A past debris source was the testing of [[anti-satellite weapon]]s (ASATs) by the U.S. and Soviet Union during the 1960s and 1970s. [[North American Aerospace Defense Command]] (NORAD) files only contained data for Soviet tests, and debris from U.S. tests were only identified later.<ref name=s48-note>Note that the list Schefter was presented only identified USSR ASAT tests.</ref> By the time the debris problem was understood, widespread ASAT testing had ended; the U.S. [[Program 437]] was shut down in 1975.<ref>Clayton Chun, "Shooting Down a Star: America's Thor Program 437, Nuclear ASAT, and Copycat Killers", Maxwell AFB Base, AL: Air University Press, 1999. {{ISBN|1-58566-071-X}}.</ref>
The U.S. restarted their ASAT programs in the 1980s with the Vought [[ASM-135 ASAT]]. A 1985 test destroyed a {{convert|1|t|lb|adj=on}} satellite orbiting at {{convert|525|km|abbr=on}}, creating thousands of debris larger than {{convert|1|cm|abbr=on}}. Due to the altitude, atmospheric drag decayed the orbit of most debris within a decade. A ''de facto'' moratorium followed the test.<ref name=brief>David Wright, [http://www.ucsusa.org/assets/documents/nwgs/debris-in-brief-factsheet.pdf "Debris in Brief: Space Debris from Anti-Satellite Weapons"] ''Union of Concerned Scientists'', December 2007.</ref>
[[File:Fengyun-1C debris.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Simulation of Earth from space, with orbit planes in red|Known orbit planes of [[Fengyun]]-1C debris one month after the weather satellite's disintegration by the [[2007 Chinese anti-satellite missile test|Chinese ASAT]]]]
China's government was condemned for the military implications and the amount of debris from the [[2007 Chinese anti-satellite missile test|2007 anti-satellite missile test]],<ref>Leonard David, [http://www.space.com/news/070202_china_spacedebris.html "China's Anti-Satellite Test: Worrisome Debris Cloud Circles Earth"] ''space.com'', 2 February 2007.</ref> the largest single space debris incident in history (creating over 2,300 pieces golf-ball size or larger, over 35,000 {{convert|1|cm|1|abbr=on}} or larger, and one million pieces {{convert|1|mm|2|abbr=on}} or larger). The target satellite orbited between {{convert|850|km|abbr=on}} and {{convert|882|km|abbr=on}}, the portion of near-Earth space most densely populated with satellites.<ref>[http://www.heavens-above.com/satinfo.aspx?lat=0&lng=0&alt=0&loc=Unspecified&TZ=CET&SatID=25730 "Fengyun 1C – Orbit Data"] ''Heavens Above''.</ref> Since atmospheric drag is low at that altitude the debris is slow to return to Earth, and in June 2007 NASA's [[Terra (satellite)|Terra environmental spacecraft]] maneuvered to avoid impact from the debris.<ref>Brian Burger, [http://www.space.com/news/070706_sn_china_terra.html "NASA's Terra Satellite Moved to Avoid Chinese ASAT Debris"], ''space.com''. Retrieved 6 July 2007.</ref>
On 20 February 2008, the U.S. launched an [[RIM-161 Standard Missile 3|SM-3 missile]] from the [[USS Lake Erie (CG-70)|USS ''Lake Erie'']] to destroy a defective U.S. spy satellite thought to be carrying {{convert|1000|lb|kg|abbr=on|order=flip}} of toxic [[hydrazine]] propellant. The event occurred at about {{convert|250|km|0|abbr=on}}, and the resulting debris has a [[Apsis|perigee]] of {{convert|250|km|0|abbr=on}} or lower.<ref>[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=19227400 "Pentagon: Missile Scored Direct Hit on Satellite."], npr.org, 21 February 2008.</ref> The missile was aimed to minimize the amount of debris, which (according to Pentagon Strategic Command chief Kevin Chilton) had decayed by early 2009.<ref>Jim Wolf, [http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKN2730646120090227 "US satellite shootdown debris said gone from space"], ''Reuters'', 27 February 2009.</ref>
The vulnerability of satellites to debris and the possibility of attacking LEO satellites to create debris clouds, has triggered speculation that it is possible for countries unable to make a precision attack.{{clarify|date=August 2017}} An attack on a satellite of 10 tonnes or more would heavily damage the LEO environment.<ref name=brief />
== {{anchor|Operational aspects}}Threats == [[File:Space debris impact on Space Shuttle window.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=Large glass pit (damage)|A [[micrometeoroid]] left this crater on the surface of Space Shuttle Challenger's front window on STS-7.]]
=== To spacecraft === Space junk is a threat to active satellites and spaceships. The [[Earth's orbit]] may even become impassable as the risk of collision grows too high.<ref name=sp1/>
==== {{anchor|Threat to unmanned spacecraft}}Unmanned spacecraft==== Although spacecraft are protected by [[Whipple shield]]s, solar panels, which are exposed to the Sun, wear from low-mass impacts. These produce a cloud of [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]] which is an electrical risk to the panels.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Akahoshi | first1 = Y. | display-authors = 1 | last2 = et al | year = 2008 | title = Influence of space debris impact on solar array under power generation | url = | journal = International Journal of Impact Engineering | volume = 35 | issue = 12| pages = 1678–1682 | doi = 10.1016/j.ijimpeng.2008.07.048 }}</ref>
Satellites are believed to have been destroyed by micrometeorites and orbital debris (MMOD). The earliest suspected loss was of Kosmos 1275, which disappeared on 24 July 1981 (a month after launch). Kosmos contained no volatile propellant, therefore, there appeared to be nothing internal to the satellite which could have caused the destructive explosion which took place. However the case has not been proven and another hypothesis forwarded is that the battery exploded. Tracking showed it broke up, into 300 new objects.
Many impacts have been confirmed since. [[Olympus-1]] was struck by a meteoroid on 11 August 1993, and left adrift.<ref name="The Olympus failure" /> On 24 July 1996, the French [[Miniaturized satellite|microsatellite]] [[Cerise (satellite)|Cerise]] was hit by fragments of an Ariane-1 H-10 upper-stage booster which exploded in November 1986.<ref name="Klinkrad, p. 2" /> On 29 March 2006, the Russian Ekspress AM11 communications satellite was struck by an unknown object and rendered inoperable;<ref name=srdc20060419 /> its engineers had sufficient time in contact with the spacecraft to send it to a [[parking orbit]] out of GEO.{{citation needed|date=February 2015}} On October 13, 2009, [[Terra (satellite)|Terra]] suffered a single battery cell failure anomaly and a battery heater control anomaly which were likely the result of an MMOD strike.<ref name="Mission Report">{{cite web|last1=Kelley|first1=Angelita|title=Terra mission operations: Launch to the present (and beyond)|url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20160008917.pdf|accessdate=5 April 2018}}</ref> On March 12, 2010, [[Aura (satellite)|Aura]] lost power from one-half of one of its 11 solar panels and this was also attributed to an MMOD strike.<ref name="2017Status">{{cite journal|last1=Fisher|first1=Dominic|title=Mission Status at Aura Science Team MOWG Meeting|date=13 June 2017|url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20170005606.pdf|accessdate=13 December 2017}}</ref> On May 22, 2013 GOES-13 was hit by an MMOD which caused it to lose track of the stars that it uses to maintain attitude. It took nearly a month for the spacecraft to return to operation.<ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20130607192921/http://www.ssd.noaa.gov/PS/SATS/MESS/MSG1422048.01.txt</ref>
The [[2009 satellite collision|first major satellite collision]] occurred on 10 February 2009 at 16:56 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]]. The deactivated {{convert|950|kg|abbr=on}} [[Kosmos 2251]] and the operational {{convert|560|kg|abbr=on}} [[Iridium 33]] collided, {{convert|500|mi|abbr=on}}<ref name="n2yo">Becky Iannotta and Tariq Malik, [http://www.space.com/news/090211-satellite-collision.html "U.S. Satellite Destroyed in Space Collision"], space.com, 11 February 2009</ref> over northern Siberia. The relative speed of impact was about {{convert|11.7|km/s|abbr=on}}, or about {{convert|42120|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref>Paul Marks, [https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn16604-satellite-collision-more-powerful-than-chinas-asat-test.html "Satellite collision 'more powerful than China's ASAT test"], ''New Scientist'', 13 February 2009.</ref> Both satellites were destroyed, with accurate estimates of the number of debris unavailable.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090214194123/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090211/ap_on_sc/satellite_collision "2 big satellites collide 500 miles over Siberia."] ''yahoo.com'', 11 February 2009. Retrieved 11 February 2009.</ref><ref name="I33-K2251">Becky Iannotta, [http://www.space.com/news/090211-satellite-collision.html "U.S. Satellite Destroyed in Space Collision"], space.com, 11 February 2009. Retrieved 11 February 2009.</ref> On 22 January 2013 [[BLITS (satellite)|BLITS]] (a Russian laser-ranging satellite) was struck by debris suspected to be from the [[2007 Chinese anti-satellite missile test]], changing its orbit and spin rate.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.space.com/20138-russian-satellite-chinese-space-junk.html |title=Russian Satellite Hit by Debris from Chinese Anti-Satellite Test |author=Leonard David |publisher=space.com}}</ref>
Satellites frequently have to perform Collision Avoidance Maneuvers and managers have to monitor debris as part of maneuver planning. For example, in January 2017, the [[European Space Agency]] planned to alter orbit of one of its $319 million<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://spacenews.com/38301swarm-satellite-trio-launched-to-study-earths-magnetic-field/|title=Swarm Satellite Trio Launched To Study Earth’s Magnetic Field - SpaceNews.com|date=2013-11-22|newspaper=SpaceNews.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-25}}</ref> [[Swarm (spacecraft)|Swarm]] mission spacecrafts, based on data from the US [[Joint Space Operations Center]], to end the risk of collision from Cosmos-375, an old Russian satellite.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/european-space-agency-orbiter-russian-satellite-space-junk-this-week/|title=Space junk could take out a European satellite this week|newspaper=CNET|language=en|access-date=2017-01-25}}</ref> Cosmos-375, which was destroyed by Soviet operators when its mission was complete, had previously threatened to impact the International Space Station in 2011.
==== {{anchor|Threat to manned spacecraft}}Manned spacecraft ====
===== Space Shuttle missions ===== [[File:Ststpstile.jpg|thumb|alt=Grey spacecraft wing at aircraft altitude|[[Space Shuttle Discovery|''Discovery''{{'}}s]] lower starboard wing and Thermal Protection System tiles, photographed on STS-114 during an R-Bar Pitch Manoeuvre where astronauts examine the TPS for any damage during ascent]] From the early [[Space Shuttle]] missions, NASA used NORAD to monitor the Shuttle's orbital path for debris. In the 1980s, this used much of its capacity.<ref name=s50 /> The first collision-avoidance maneuver occurred during [[STS-48]] in September 1991,<ref name=encounters>Rob Matson, [http://www.satobs.org/satclose.html "Satellite Encounters"] ''Visual Satellite Observer's Home Page''.</ref> a seven-second [[reaction control system|thruster burn]] to avoid debris from [[Kosmos 955]].<ref>[https://www.scribd.com/doc/52642978/STS-48-Space-Shuttle-Mission-Report "STS-48 Space Shuttle Mission Report"], NASA, NASA-CR-193060, October 1991.</ref> Similar maneuvers followed on missions 53, 72 and 82.<ref name=encounters />
One of the first events to publicize the debris problem occurred on [[Space Shuttle Challenger|''Challenger'']]'s second flight, [[STS-7]]. A fleck of paint struck its front window, creating a pit over {{Convert|1|mm|2|abbr=on}} wide. On [[STS-59]] in 1994, [[Space Shuttle Endeavour|''Endeavour'']]'s front window was pitted about half its depth. Minor debris impacts increased from 1998.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Christiansen | first1 = E. L. | last2 = Hyden | first2 = J. L. | last3 = Bernhard | first3 = R. P. | year = 2004 | title = Space Shuttle debris and meteoroid impacts | url = | journal = Advances in Space Research | volume = 34 | issue = 5| pages = 1097–1103 | doi = 10.1016/j.asr.2003.12.008 | bibcode=2004AdSpR..34.1097C}}</ref>
Window chipping and minor damage to [[Space Shuttle thermal protection system|thermal protection system tiles]] (TPS) was already common by the 1990s. The Shuttle was later flown tail-first to take the debris load mostly on the engines and rear cargo bay (not used in orbit or during descent, and less critical for post-launch operation). When flying to the [[International Space Station|ISS]], the two connected spacecraft were flipped around so the better-armored station shielded the orbiter.<ref name=threat />
[[File:STS-118 debris entry.jpg|left|thumb|alt=Bullet-like hole in metallic material|[[Space Shuttle Endeavour|Space Shuttle ''Endeavour'']] had a major impact on its radiator during STS-118. The entry hole is about {{frac|1|4}} inch, and the exit hole is twice as large.]] NASA's study concluded that debris accounted for half of the overall risk to the Shuttle.<ref name=threat>Kelly, John. [http://www.space.com/missionlaunches/050305_shuttle_debris.html "Debris is Shuttle's Biggest Threat"], space.com, 5 March 2005.</ref><ref>"Debris Danger". ''Aviation Week & Space Technology'', Volume 169 Number 10 (15 September 2008), p. 18.</ref> Executive-level decision to proceed was required if catastrophic impact was likelier than 1 in 200. On a normal (low-orbit) mission to the ISS the risk was c. 1 in 300, but [[STS-125]] (the [[Hubble Space Telescope|Hubble]] repair mission) at {{convert|350|mi|km|abbr=on}} was initially calculated at a 1-in-185 risk (due to the [[2009 satellite collision]]). A re-analysis with better debris numbers reduced the estimated risk to 1 in 221, and the mission went ahead.<ref>William Harwood, [http://www.spaceflightnow.com/shuttle/sts125/090416debris/ "Improved odds ease NASA's concerns about space debris"], ''CBS News'', 16 April 2009.</ref>
Debris incidents continued on later Shuttle missions. During [[STS-115]] in 2006 a fragment of [[circuit board]] bored a small hole through the radiator panels in [[Space Shuttle Atlantis|''Atlantis'']]' cargo bay.<ref>D. Lear et al, [http://pdf.aiaa.org/preview/CDReadyMSDM09_2047/PV2009_2361.pdf "Investigation of Shuttle Radiator Micro-Meteoroid & Orbital Debris Damage"] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/5sq1465fR?url=http://pdf.aiaa.org/preview/CDReadyMSDM09_2047/PV2009_2361.pdf |date=18 September 2010 }}, ''Proceedings of the 50th Structures, Structural Dynamics, and Materials Conference'', 4–7 May 2009, AIAA 2009–2361.</ref> On [[STS-118]] in 2007 debris blew a bullet-like hole through ''Endeavour''{{'}}s radiator panel.<ref>D. Lear, et al, [https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20080010742_2008009999.pdf "STS-118 Radiator Impact Damage"], NASA</ref>
===== Mir ===== Impact wear was notable on [[Mir]], the Soviet space station, since it remained in space for long periods with its original module panels.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Smirnov | first1 = V.M. | display-authors = 1 | last2 = et al | year = 2000 | title = Study of Micrometeoroid and Orbital Debris Effects on the Solar Panelson 'MIR' | url = | journal = Space Debris | volume = 2 | issue = 1| pages = 1–7 | doi = 10.1023/A:1015607813420 }}</ref><ref>[http://orbitaldebris.jsc.nasa.gov/faqs.html#9 "Orbital Debris FAQ: How did the Mir space station fare during its 15-year stay in Earth orbit?"], ''NASA'', July 2009.</ref>
[[File:Mir on 12 June 1998edit1.jpg|left|thumb|alt=Space station with Earth as the background|Debris impacts on Mir's solar panels degraded their performance. The damage is most noticeable on the panel on the right, which is facing the camera with a high degree of contrast. Extensive damage to the smaller panel below is due to impact with a Progress spacecraft.]]
===== International Space Station ===== Although the ISS uses [[Whipple shield]]ing to protect itself from minor debris,<ref>K Thoma et al, [http://www.cosis.net/abstracts/SPACE2005/00155/SPACE2005-A-00155.pdf "New Protection Concepts for Meteoroid / Debris Shields"], ''Proceedings of the 4th European Conference on Space Debris'' (ESA SP-587), 18–20 April 2005, p. 445.</ref> portions (notably its [[solar panel]]s) cannot be protected easily. In 1989, the ISS panels were predicted to degrade c. 0.23% in four years, and they were overdesigned by 1%.<ref>Henry Nahra, [https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19890016664_1989016664.pdf "Effect of Micrometeoroid and Space Debris Impacts on the Space Station Freedom Solar Array Surfaces"]. Presented at the 1989 Spring Meeting of the Materials Research Society, 24–29 April 1989, NASA TR-102287.</ref> A maneuver is performed if "there is a greater than one-in-10,000 chance of a debris strike".<ref name=sn20140116 /> {{asof|2014|01}}, there have been sixteen maneuvers in the fifteen years the ISS had been in orbit.<ref name=sn20140116 />
The crew sheltered in the [[Soyuz spacecraft|Soyuz]] on three occasions due to late debris-proximity warnings. In addition to the sixteen firings and three Soyuz-capsule shelter orders, one attempted maneuver failed (due to not having the several days' warning necessary to upload the manoeuvre timeline to the station's computer).<ref name=sn20140116 /><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/7940431.stm "Junk alert for space station crew"], BBC News, 12 March 2009.</ref><ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-13949956 "International Space Station in debris scare"], BBC News, 28 June 2011.</ref> A March 2009 close call involved debris believed to be a {{convert|10|cm|abbr=on}} piece of the Kosmos 1275 satellite.<ref>Haines, Lester. [https://www.theregister.co.uk/2009/03/17/iss_update/ "ISS spared space junk avoidance manoeuvre"], ''The Register'', 17 March 2009.</ref> In 2013, the ISS did not [[orbital maneuver|maneuver]] to avoid debris, after a record four debris maneuvers the previous year.<ref name=sn20140116>{{cite news |last=de Selding|first=Peter B. |title=Space Station Required No Evasive Maneuvers in 2013 Despite Growing Debris Threat |url=http://www.spacenews.com/article/civil-space/39121space-station-required-no-evasive-maneuvers-in-2013-despite-growing-debris |accessdate=2014-01-17 |newspaper=Space News |date=2014-01-16}}</ref>
==== {{anchor|Kessler Syndrome and manned spacecraft}}Kessler syndrome ==== {{Main|Kessler syndrome}} Although most manned space activity takes place at altitudes below {{convert|800|to|1500|km|abbr=on}}, a Kessler syndrome cascade in that region would rain down into lower altitudes and the decay time scale is such that "the resulting [low Earth orbit] debris environment is likely to be too hostile for future space use".<ref name=k9163>Kessler 1991, p. 63.</ref><ref>Bechara J. Saab, [http://www.hypothesisjournal.com/?p=828 "Planet Earth, Space Debris"], ''Hypothesis'' Volume 7 Issue 1 (September 2009).</ref>
In a Kessler syndrome, satellite lifetimes would be measured in years or months. New satellites could be launched through the debris field into higher orbits or placed in lower orbits (where decay removes the debris), but the utility of the region between {{convert|800|and|1500|km|abbr=on}} is the reason for its amount of debris.<ref name=graph />
=== {{anchor|Hazard on Earth}}To Earth === [[File:PAM-D module crash in Saudi Arabian desert.png|thumb|alt=Cylindrical rocket fragment on sand, with men looking at it|Saudi officials inspect a crashed PAM-D module in January 2001.]] Although most debris burns up in the atmosphere, larger objects can reach the ground intact. According to NASA, an average of one cataloged piece of debris has fallen back to Earth each day for the past 50 years. Despite their size, there has been no significant property damage from the debris.<ref>Brown, M. (2012). Orbital Debris Frequently Asked Questions. Retrieved from http://orbitaldebris.jsc.nasa.gov/faqs.html.</ref>
In 1969 five sailors on a Japanese ship were injured by space debris.<ref>U.S. Congress, Office of Technology Assessment, [https://fas.org/ota/reports/9033.pdf "Orbiting Debris: A Space Environmental Problem"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304000243/http://www.fas.org/ota/reports/9033.pdf |date=4 March 2016 }}, Background Paper, OTA-BP-ISC-72, U.S. Government Printing Office, September 1990, p. 3</ref> In 1997 an Oklahoma woman, Lottie Williams, was injured when she was hit in the shoulder by a {{convert|10|x|13|cm|abbr=on}} piece of blackened, woven metallic material confirmed as part of the propellant tank of a [[Delta II]] rocket which launched a U.S. Air Force satellite the year before.<ref>[http://www.todayinsci.com/1/1_22.htm "Today in Science History"] ''todayinsci.com''. Retrieved 8 March 2006.</ref><ref>Tony Long, [https://www.wired.com/2009/01/jan-22-1997-heads-up-lottie-its-space-junk/ "Jan. 22, 1997: Heads Up, Lottie! It's Space Junk!"], ''wired'', 22 January 2009. Retrieved 27 March 2016</ref>
The original re-entry plan for [[Skylab]] called for the station to remain in space for eight to ten years after its final mission in February 1974. High solar activity expanded the upper atmosphere, resulting in higher-than-expected drag and bringing its orbit closer to Earth than planned. On 11 July 1979 Skylab re-entered the Earth's atmosphere and disintegrated, raining debris along a path over the southern Indian Ocean and Western Australia.<ref>[http://www.nasa.gov/missions/shuttle/f_skylab1.html "NASA – Part I – The History of Skylab."] ''NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center and Kennedy Space Center'', 16 March 2009.</ref><ref>[http://www.nasa.gov/centers/kennedy/about/history/story/ch10.html "NASA – John F. Kennedy Space Center Story."] [[NASA]] Kennedy Space Center, 16 March 2009.</ref>
On 12 January 2001, a [[Star 48]] [[Payload Assist Module]] (PAM-D) rocket upper stage re-entered the atmosphere after a "catastrophic orbital decay",<ref name='orb_debris'>[http://orbitaldebris.jsc.nasa.gov/newsletter/pdfs/ODQNv6i2.pdf "PAM-D Debris Falls in Saudi Arabia"], ''The Orbital Debris Quarterly News'', Volume 6 Issue 2 (April 2001).</ref> crashing in the Saudi Arabian desert. It was identified as the upper-stage rocket for [[GPS satellite blocks#Block IIA series|NAVSTAR 32]], a [[GPS]] satellite launched in 1993.
In the 2003 [[Columbia disaster|''Columbia'' disaster]], large parts of the spacecraft reached the ground and entire equipment systems remained intact.<ref>[https://history.nasa.gov/columbia/debris_pics.html "Debris Photos"] ''NASA''.</ref> More than 83,000 pieces, along with the remains of the six astronauts, were recovered in an area from three to 10 miles around Hemphill in Sabine County, TX.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wallach|first1=Dan|title=Columbia shuttle tragedy marks Sabine County town|url=https://www.beaumontenterprise.com/news/article/Columbia-shuttle-tragedy-marks-Sabine-County-town-6798276.php|accessdate=8 May 2018|date=1 February 2016}}</ref> More pieces were found in a line from west Texas to east Louisiana, with the westernmost piece found in Littlefield, TX and the easternmost found southwest of Mora, LA.<ref>{{cite web|title=Columbia Accident Investigation Report, Volume II Appendix D.10|url=https://caib1.nasa.gov/news/report/pdf/vol2/part10.pdf|accessdate=10 May 2018|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111017154539/https://caib1.nasa.gov/news/report/pdf/vol2/part10.pdf|archivedate=17 October 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Although there is significant evidence that debris fell in Nevada, Utah, and New Mexico, debris was only found in Texas, Arkansas and Louisiana. In a rare case of property damage, a foot-long metal bracket smashed through the roof of a dentist office.<ref>{{cite news|title=Shuttle Debris Falls on East Texas, Louisiana|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2003/02/01/shuttle-debris-falls-on-east-texas-louisiana.html|accessdate=8 May 2018|date=1 February 2003}}</ref> NASA warned the public to avoid contact with the debris because of the possible presence of hazardous chemicals.<ref>[http://www.nasa.gov/columbia/help/ "Debris Warning"] ''NASA''.</ref> 15 years after the failure, people were still sending in pieces with the last,as of February 1, 2018, found in the spring of 2017.<ref>{{cite news|title=Debris from fallen space shuttle Columbia has new mission 15 years after tragedy|url=http://www.collectspace.com/news/news-020118a-columbia-debris-lessons-learned.html|accessdate=8 May 2018|date=1 February 2018}}</ref>
On 27 March 2007, airborne debris from a Russian [[spy satellite]] was seen by the pilot of a [[LAN Airlines]] [[Airbus A340]] carrying 270 passengers whilst flying over the Pacific Ocean between [[Santiago]] and [[Auckland]]. The debris was within {{convert|5|nmi}} of the aircraft.<ref>Jano Gibson, [http://www.smh.com.au/news/travel/jets-flaming-space-junk-scare/2007/03/28/1174761528947.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap1 "Jet's flaming space junk scare"], ''The Sydney Morning Herald'', 28 March 2007.</ref>
== Tracking and measurement ==
=== Tracking from the ground === Radar and optical detectors such as [[lidar]] are the main tools for tracking space debris. Although objects under {{convert|10|cm|0|abbr=on}} have reduced orbital stability, debris as small as 1 cm can be tracked,<ref>D. Mehrholz et al;[http://www.esa.int/esapub/bulletin/bullet109/chapter16_bul109.pdf "Detecting, Tracking and Imaging Space Debris"], ESA bulletin 109, February 2002.</ref><ref>Ben Greene, [http://cddis.nasa.gov/lw13/docs/papers/adv_greene_1m.pdf "Laser Tracking of Space Debris"], Electro Optic Systems Pty</ref> however determining orbits to allow re-acquisition is difficult. Most debris remain unobserved. The [[NASA Orbital Debris Observatory]] tracked space debris with a {{convert|3|m|0|abbr=on}} [[Liquid mirror telescopes|liquid mirror]] [[transit telescope]].<ref>[http://orbitaldebris.jsc.nasa.gov/measure/optical.html "Orbital debris: Optical Measurements"], NASA Orbital Debris Program Office</ref> FM Radio waves can detect debris, after reflecting off them onto a receiver.<ref>{{cite web|last=Pantaleo|first=Rick|title=Australian Scientists Track Space Junk by Listening to FM Radio|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/australian-scientists-track-space-junk-by-listening-to-fm-radio/1801950.html|work=web|accessdate=3 December 2013}}</ref> Optical tracking may be a useful early-warning system on spacecraft.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/j.actaastro.2014.07.031|title=Optical orbital debris spotter|journal=Acta Astronautica|volume=104|pages=99–105|year=2014|last1=Englert|first1=Christoph R.|last2=Bays|first2=J. Timothy|last3=Marr|first3=Kenneth D.|last4=Brown|first4=Charles M.|last5=Nicholas|first5=Andrew C.|last6=Finne|first6=Theodore T.|bibcode=2014AcAau.104...99E}}</ref>
The [[United States Strategic Command|U.S. Strategic Command]] keeps a catalog of known orbital objects, using ground-based [[radar]] and telescopes, and a space-based telescope (originally to distinguish from hostile missiles). The 2009 edition listed about 19,000 objects.<ref>Grant Stokes et al, [https://web.archive.org/web/20080327212602/http://www.ll.mit.edu/ST/sbv/sbv_table_of_contents.html "The Space-Based Visible Program"], ''MIT Lincoln Laboratory''. Retrieved 8 March 2006.</ref> Other data come from the [[ESA Space Debris Telescope]], [[TIRA (System)|TIRA]],<ref>H. Klinkrad, [https://fas.org/spp/military/program/track/klinkrad.pdf "Monitoring Space – Efforts Made by European Countries"], ''fas.org''. Retrieved 8 March 2006.</ref> the [[Goldstone Deep Space Communications Complex|Goldstone]], [[Haystack Observatory|Haystack]],<ref>[http://www.haystack.mit.edu/ "MIT Haystack Observatory"] haystack.mit.edu. Retrieved 8 March 2006.</ref> and [[EISCAT]] radars and the [[Cobra Dane]] [[phased array]] radar,<ref>[https://fas.org/spp/military/program/track/cobra_dane.htm "AN/FPS-108 COBRA DANE."] ''fas.org''. Retrieved 8 March 2006.</ref> to be used in debris-environment models like the ESA Meteoroid and Space Debris Terrestrial Environment Reference (MASTER).
=== Measurement in space === [[File:STS-41-C-LDEF-deploy-small.jpg|left|thumb|alt=Large, cylindrical spacecraft against Earth background, photographed from the ''Challenger'' space shuttle|The [[Long Duration Exposure Facility]] (LDEF) is an important source of information on small-particle space debris.]] Returned space hardware is a valuable source of information on the directional distribution and composition of the (sub-millimetre) debris flux. The [[LDEF]] satellite deployed by mission [[STS-41-C]] ''[[Space Shuttle Challenger|Challenger]]'' and retrieved by [[STS-32]] ''[[Space Shuttle Columbia|Columbia]]'' spent 68 months in orbit to gather debris data. The [[European Retrievable Carrier|EURECA]] satellite, deployed by [[STS-46]] ''[[Space Shuttle Atlantis|Atlantis]]'' in 1992 and retrieved by [[STS-57]] ''[[Space Shuttle Endeavour|Endeavour]]'' in 1993, was also used for debris study.<ref>Darius Nikanpour, [https://www.mcgill.ca/files/iasl/Session_1_Darius_Nikanpour.pdf "Space Debris Mitigation Technologies"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019134008/http://www.mcgill.ca/files/iasl/Session_1_Darius_Nikanpour.pdf |date=19 October 2012 }}, ''Proceedings of the Space Debris Congress'', 7–9 May 2009.</ref>
The [[Photovoltaic system|solar arrays]] of [[Hubble Space Telescope|Hubble]] were returned by missions [[STS-61]] ''Endeavour'' and [[STS-109]] ''Columbia'', and the [[impact craters]] studied by the ESA to validate its models. Materials returned from Mir were also studied, notably the [[Mir Environmental Effects Payload]] (which also tested materials intended for the ISS<ref name="MEEP PR">{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/centers/langley/news/releases/1996/Mar96/96_13.html|accessdate=8 March 2011|date=March 1996|title=STS-76 Mir Environmental Effects Payload (MEEP)|publisher=NASA}}</ref>).<ref>[http://spaceflight.nasa.gov/history/shuttle-mir/spacecraft/s-mir-meep-main.htm MEEP], NASA, 4 April 2002. Retrieved 8 July 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.nasa.gov/centers/langley/news/releases/1996/Mar96/96_13.html "STS-76 Mir Environmental Effects Payload (MEEP)"], NASA, March 1996. Retrieved 8 March 2011.</ref>
=== Gabbard diagrams === A debris cloud resulting from a single event is studied with [[scatter plot]]s known as Gabbard diagrams, where the [[perigee]] and [[apogee]] of fragments are plotted with respect to their [[orbital period]]. Gabbard diagrams of the early debris cloud prior to the effects of perturbations, if the data were available, are reconstructed. They often include data on newly observed, as yet uncatalogued fragments. Gabbard diagrams can provide important insights into the features of the fragmentation, the direction and point of impact.<ref name=portree>David Portree and Joseph Loftus. [http://ston.jsc.nasa.gov/collections/TRS/_techrep/TP-1999-208856.pdf "Orbital Debris: A Chronology"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20000901071135/http://ston.jsc.nasa.gov/collections/TRS/_techrep/TP-1999-208856.pdf |date=1 September 2000 }}, NASA, 1999, p. 13.</ref><ref>David Whitlock, [http://www.orbitaldebris.jsc.nasa.gov/library/SatelliteFragHistory/13thEditionofBreakupBook.pdf "History of On-Orbit Satellite Fragmentations"], NASA JSC, 2004</ref>
== Dealing with debris == An average of about one tracked object per day has been dropping out of orbit for the past 50 years,<ref name=ss20111205b /> averaging almost three objects per day at [[solar maximum]] (due to the heating and expansion of the Earth's atmosphere), but one about every three days at [[solar minimum]], usually 5½ yr later.<ref name=ss20111205b>{{cite web |last=Johnson |first=Nicholas |title=Space debris issues |date=5 December 2011 |url=http://www.thespaceshow.com/detail.asp?q=1666 |work=audio file, @0:05:50-0:07:40 |publisher=The Space Show |accessdate=8 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120127055806/http://thespaceshow.com/detail.asp?q=1666 |archivedate=27 January 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In addition to natural atmospheric effects, corporations, academics and government agencies have proposed plans and technology to deal with space debris, but {{asof|2014|11|lc=y}}, most of these are theoretical, and there is no extant business plan for debris reduction.<ref name=sn20141125/>
A number of scholars have also observed that [[Institution|institutional factors]]—political, legal, economic and cultural "rules of the game"—are the greatest impediment to the cleanup of near-Earth space. There is no commercial incentive, since [[Negative externality|costs aren't assigned to polluters]], but a number of suggestions have been made.<ref name=sn20141125>{{cite news |last1=Foust|first1=Jeff |title=Companies Have Technologies, but Not Business Plans, for Orbital Debris Cleanup |url=http://www.spacenews.com/article/civil-space/42656companies-have-technologies-but-not-business-plans-for-orbital-debris |accessdate=2014-12-06 |work=Space News |date=2014-11-25 }}</ref> However, effects to date are limited. In the US, governmental bodies have been accused of backsliding on previous commitments to limit debris growth, "let alone tackling the more complex issues of removing orbital debris."<ref name=sn20141124>{{cite news |last1=Foust|first1=Jeff |title=Industry Worries Government ‘Backsliding’ on Orbital Debris |url=http://www.spacenews.com/article/civil-space/42634industry-worries-government-%E2%80%98backsliding%E2%80%99-on-orbital-debris |archive-url=https://archive.is/20141208181506/http://www.spacenews.com/article/civil-space/42634industry-worries-government-%E2%80%98backsliding%E2%80%99-on-orbital-debris |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2014-12-08 |accessdate=2014-12-08 |work=Space News |date=2014-11-24 |quote=''Despite growing concern about the threat posed by orbital debris, and language in U.S. national space policy directing government agencies to study debris cleanup technologies, many in the space community worry that the government is not doing enough to implement that policy.'' }}</ref>
=== Growth mitigation === [[File:SpaceDebrisHistogram.png|thumb|alt=Graph with blue line|Spatial density of LEO space debris by altitude, according to 2011 a NASA report to the [[United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs]]<ref>{{cite web|title=USA Space Debris Envinronment, Operations, and Policy Updates|url=http://www.oose.unvienna.org/pdf/pres/stsc2011/tech-31.pdf|work=NASA|publisher=UNOOSA|accessdate=1 October 2011}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=Balon Greyjoy |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>]] [[File:Spacedebris small.png|thumb|alt=Graph with red line|Spatial density of space debris by altitude according to ESA MASTER-2001, without debris from the Chinese ASAT and 2009 collision events]] Upper stage [[Passivation (spacecraft)|passivation]] (e.g. of [[Delta (rocket family)|Delta boosters]]<ref name=s50 />) by releasing residual propellants reduces debris from orbital explosions; however not all boosters implement this.<ref name=ss20111205>{{cite web |last=Johnson |first=Nicholas |title=Space debris issues |date=5 December 2011 |url=http://www.thespaceshow.com/detail.asp?q=1666 |work=audio file, @1:03:05-1:06:20 |publisher=The Space Show |accessdate=8 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120127055806/http://thespaceshow.com/detail.asp?q=1666 |archivedate=27 January 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Although there is no international treaty minimizing space debris, the [[United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space]] (COPUOS) published voluntary guidelines in 2007.<ref>[http://orbitaldebris.jsc.nasa.gov/library/Space%20Debris%20Mitigation%20Guidelines_COPUOS.pdf "UN Space Debris Mitigation Guidelines"], UN Office for Outer Space Affairs, 2010.</ref> As of 2008, the committee is discussing international "rules of the road" to prevent collisions between satellites.<ref>Theresa Hitchens, [http://www.thebulletin.org/web-edition/features/copuos-wades-the-next-great-space-debate "COPUOS Wades into the Next Great Space Debate"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081226123125/http://thebulletin.org/web-edition/features/copuos-wades-the-next-great-space-debate |date=26 December 2008 }}, ''The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists'', 26 June 2008.</ref> By 2013, various legal regimes existed, typically instantiated in the launch licenses that are required for a launch in all spacefaring [[Nation state|nations]].<ref name=ssm20130718> {{cite news |url=http://www.spacesafetymagazine.com/space-debris/mitigation/compliance-rocket-upper-stage-gto-space-debris-mitigation-guidelines/ |title=Compliance of Rocket Upper Stages in GTO with Space Debris Mitigation Guidelines |work=Space Safety Magazine |date=2013-07-18 |accessdate=2016-02-16 }}</ref>
The U.S. has a set of standard practices for civilian ([[NASA]]) and military ([[United States Department of Defense|DoD]] and [[USAF]]) orbital-debris mitigation,<ref name=us20131128>{{cite web |title=U.S. Government Orbital Debris Mitigation Standard Practices |url=http://orbitaldebris.jsc.nasa.gov/library/USG_OD_Standard_Practices.pdf |publisher=United States Federal Government |accessdate=2013-11-28 }}</ref><ref name=nasaOrbDebris>[http://orbitaldebris.jsc.nasa.gov/library/references.html "Orbital Debris – Important Reference Documents."], NASA Orbital Debris Program Office.</ref> as has the [[European Space Agency]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Operations/Space_Debris/Mitigating_space_debris_generation |title=Mitigating space debris generation |date=19 Apr 2013 |publisher=European Space Agency |accessdate=27 Jul 2014}}</ref> In 2007, the [[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] began preparing an [[international standard]] for space-debris mitigation.<ref>E A Taylor and J R Davey, [http://pig.sagepub.com/content/221/6/987.full.pdf "Implementation of debris mitigation using International Organization for Standardization (ISO) standards"], ''Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers: G,'' Volume 221 Number 8 (1 June 2007), pp. 987 – 996.</ref> Germany and France have posted [[Bond (finance)|bonds]] to safeguard property from debris damage.<ref>Howell, E. (2013). Experts Urge Removal of Space Debris From Orbit. ''Universe Today''. Retrieved from http://www.universetoday.com/101790/experts-urge-removal-of-space-debris-from-orbit/</ref>
